Posts.Content: I am new here but not new to cancer. My grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer in the 80's. Stage 4 affected most of her lymph nodes. Six months of the red death....she lived and did not die of breast cancer. She died at the age of 90 because she lost my grandfather. A note to make is that two of her sisters DID die of breast cancer. My mother was diagnosed with stage 3 cancer 12 years ago. She did chemo for six months and then a radical masectomy. While she is cancer free....her breast reconstruction did not work. She is unable to lift her arms. (subsequently her younger sister was also diagnosed with breast cancer) I now have breast cancer. I also have a daughter and grandaughter. Chemo is kicking my ASS....the oncologist said that they have made so MANY advances. Really???? I am sick daily....my head, bones and memory hurt. Here I get off kilter....I have wondered for years, if there were a penis cancer? Would it take this long to cure????? I think not.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Biopsy?

Posts.Content: Traci~ I don't want to interrupt your chain but I will. There is hope for you and his name is Dr. Greg Annigan here in Dallas. I don't work for him or anything but he tends to clean up other plastic surgeons mistakes. I hope that you will at least check him out. Everyone needs to look and feel their best after BC. I am so very sorry that you have had the same experience that my mother experienced. When I heard your story...I had to respond. I hope I haven't overstepped my boundaries. Every woman with BC deserves to look and feel their best. Dariff
Posts.Title: Big decisions

Posts.Content: You are so VERY young and you should have GREAT breast surgeons in your area! I too have breast cancer and am going through chemo. (to allegedly shrink the tumor) I tell you this because my mother did the same thing 12 years ago. She chose to have chemo for six months and a double masectomy with immediate reconstruction. Alas it didn't work...we are now looking at surgeons that will be able to operate on her so she can just lift her arms. I will not make the same decisions. I hope I am not coming across as angry...but I am. I am VERY angry. Doubt and double check everything you are told. Trust your instincts. Dariff Originally Posted by Thoughtful I am a 31 year old woman who has is going through chemo for breast cancer. At the end of the chemo I am due for surgery. Initially it looked like just the lump being removed and now, with genetic testing and being high risk anyway, I've been asked to consider having both breasts removed. I'm told it reduces my chances of getting breast cancer again by 90% - which is such a high percentage I cannot ignore it. I have reconciled with myself that having both removed is the sensible thing but I am scared about having the strength to go through with it and looking at myself in the mirror between surgery and reconstruction. I also worry how it will affect me as a woman and my future self image with my partner. I know there are plenty of others out there who have done this and could give some advice...I do not mean it to sound more worried for how I look than my life, it's more about me as a woman and feeling confident in myself.
Posts.Title: Big decisions

Posts.Content: I bought two wigs (over $400.00) Have never worn them...never will. Before BC I had long, thick semi-curly red hair. At my house I go bald...when I go out I just wear a ball cap. The other day...I was at the grocery store, and a man stared at me a loooooong time. I knew that he was looking at my chemo head. (under my Texas Ranger ballcap) After a few minutes of his staring...I lifted my ballcap and asked "have you not seen cancer before?" Luckily his boyfriend rescued him .
Posts.Title: How much did you use your wig during hair-loss chemo?

Posts.Content: You have To RUN to an Oncologist...........NOW. I know you are afraid....we all ARE. I will hold your hand through this, I promise you. The diagnostic part of breast cancer is the hardest. Once you know WHAT you are fighting we can do it together. I WILL not leave you. Many, many women like those in my family BEAT breast cancer daily. You will do the same...I have great faith in you. Dariff
